content.webTitle: Women, and women of color, running for seats in Congress are setting a record

fields.headline: Women, and women of color, running for seats in Congress are setting a record
fields.bodyText: A record number of women, including a record number of women of color, could be elected to Congress on Tuesday, in what would represent a further step towards a US government that represents the makeup of the nation. An unprecedented 318 women are running as Democratic or Republican candidates for the 470 seats available across the House of Representatives and the Senate, up from a previous record of 257 set in 2018. Of those candidates 117 are women of color, building on the midterm elections of two years ago which saw high-profile women such as Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, in New York, and Ilhan Omar, in Minnesota, elected. By early Wednesday, 13 non-incumbent women had been elected to the House and one to the Senate. Of those, seven were Democrats and six Republicans. In Missouri, Cori Bush, a nurse who cut her teeth politically during anti-police brutality protests in Ferguson in 2014, was elected to the House of Representatives for the state’s first district. The election of Bush, a progressive, was a boost for the left of the Democratic party. “Today, I became the first Black woman elected to represent Missouri in Congress,” tweeted Bush, who also shared a photo of herself with the congressional portrait of Shirley Chisholm, the first Black woman in Congress. “It’s 2020. I shouldn’t be the first, but I am honored to carry this responsibility.” Bush’s district includes St Louis and Ferguson, where she rose to prominence as a fearless activist after the police shooting of Michael Brown. Bush’s election came 2,278 days after Brown’s killing, Bush noted following her victory. “Today we take this fight for Black Lives from the streets of Ferguson to the halls of Congress. We will get justice.” Teresa Leger Fernandez clinched a victory in New Mexico. She will join Deb Haaland, a Native American woman who was elected in 2018, in the House. Like Haaland, Leger Fernandez is a progressive Democrat, and she was endorsed by Elizabeth Warren and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez during her campaign. The makeup of Leger Fernandez’s third district is notably diverse: 40% Latino and 20% Native American. Texas could see Candace Valenzuela triumph in the state’s 24th congressional district, though early on Wednesday she trailed narrowly with 76% of the vote reporting. Valenzuela would become the first Black Latina in Congress, if she wins a district that has voted Republican since 2005. In October Valenzuela told the Guardian it was “time that the folks in power reflect the communities they serve”. “As we see more women and women of color running for and winning seats in office, we’re seeing the focus of our elected officials shift towards working families and the challenges they face,” she said. Joyce Elliot, an Arkansas state senator, attempted to become Arkansas’s first ever Black member of Congress, but failed to knock off incumbent French Hill as the state again elected an entirely Republican delegation to the House. In Georgia’s fifth congressional district – the longtime seat of the civil rights icon John Lewis – Democrat Nikema Williams, a Black woman and chair of the state’s Democratic party, handily beat Republican Angela Stanton-King. Among the newly elected Republican women are Cynthia Lummis, who won the Senate race in Wyoming, and Maria Elvira Salazar, a Cuban American Republican and longtime broadcast journalist who defeated the Democratic incumbent Donna Shalala. Only 48 of the 535 members of the House and Senate are women of color, according to the Center for American Women and Politics. There are 127 women in Congress overall. The majority of female candidates this year are Democrats, although there has been an increase in the number of female Republican candidates from 2018. Two years ago Ocasio-Cortez, Omar, Rashida Tlaib and Ayanna Pressley became high-profile additions to Congress. All four won re-election on Tuesday. • This article was amended on 4 November 2020 to give a total of 470 seats up for election across the House and Senate, instead of 535. Thirty-five of the Senate’s seats are in play this year.
